Award.AwardTitle: Mechanotransduction from Cells to Tissues: Mechanisms and Physiological Significance

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Mechanical cues are essential for life. They determine how tissues organize in embryos, and they guide tissue regeneration and even plant growth. Cells use proteins to connect to each other, and also to sense the forces between them. Discovering how the cells convert forces on the connecting proteins into chemical signals is the goal of this research. The importance of this work is to build an understanding of how mechanical inputs at the cell level control the tissue physiology, shape, size and strength. At the cell level, the research will establish how the networks of adhesion proteins that connect between the cells modify the mechanical properties of the cells. The next question to answer is how the cell level changes mechanically change the tissue level mechanical properties. As part of this project, the research investigators will work with local high school and middle school girls and underrepresented minorities to teach how science can be an interesting career.

The broad goals of this program are to establish how mechano-sensitive adhesion proteins integrate mechanical cues to regulate cell mechanics, the propagation of mechanical information through tissues, and the regulation of tissue functions. Under Aim 1, combined magnetic twisting cytometry and traction force microscopy will enable us to identify biochemical and mechanical mechanisms integrating E-cadherin force transduction signaling to integrin activation at the basal plane and increased cell contractility. Aim 2 of this proposal uses biochemical perturbations and dynamic fluorescence imaging, in conjunction with mechanical perturbations, to establish mechanisms by which force transduction signals are propagated across cell boundaries to the surrounding tissue. In Aim 3, we then demonstrate the physiological consequences of altered tissue mechanics on the permeability of epithelial tissues. The latter studies will investigate the impact on hydraulic pressure and tissue mechanics on the regulation of macromolecules flux across epithelial tissue. The intellectual significance of this work will be the identification of multiscale, mechano-transduction mechanisms that are essential for establishing comprehensive, predictive models of mechanobiology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this program was to identify mechanisms by which cells transduce force at adhesive contacts between cells in tissues. Establishing how cells respond to mechanical changes in their environment is central to understanding mechanical processes in physiology such as morphogenesis, wound healing, or the response of blood vessels to changes in blood pressure or blood flow rates. This project focused on how force is transduced by cadherins, which are critical adhesion proteins that bind cells together in all tissues. Three major outcomes of this project are as follows. First and most significantly, we identified a new mechanism by which cadherins transduces force. In this mechanism, tugging forces on cadherins on cell surfaces activate growth factor receptor signaling as well as a second class of adhesion proteins, integrins which bind cells to the extracellular matrix. The intellectual merit is the transformative discovery that cadherins, integrins, and growth factor receptors constitute an integrated force-sensitive network that together controls how cells respond to mechanical changes. It also directly links force on cadherins to signals that promote cell proliferation. Second, we established that different cadherin subtypes selectively interact with specific growth factor receptors to form the core components of mechanical switches at cell-cell adhesions. The expression of different cadherin subtypes is tightly restricted to different tissues. The intellectual merit is the new finding that specific pairwise association of cadherins and growth factor receptors constitute tissue-specific force transduction components at cell-cell contacts.  A third outcome is the demonstration that integrin-dependent signals in response to the composition and rigidity of the extracellular matrix feed back to regulate force transduction responses at cell-cell junctions. Integrins sense the extracellular matrix stiffness to regulate signaling in cells. Our findings show that integrin-dependent signals impinge on cell-cell junctions to alter cadherin-dependent force transduction. This finding reveals how differences in extracellular matrix such as in fibrotic versus normal tissues will alter force transduction responses at cell-cell contacts (intellectual merit). We further demonstrated how cooperation between these adhesion proteins and growth factor receptors regulate mechanically induced changes in the permeability (leakiness) of important tissues such as the vascular endothelium or the intestinal epithelium.  These findings transform how we think about biological force transduction because studies typically focus on a single class of adhesion receptors, such as integrins. However, our project outcomes demonstrate that different classes of adhesion receptors (cadherins and integrins) are intimately connected through signaling pathways. These findings have broad significance for mechanotransduction in tissues.

The broader impacts of this project include technology development and outreach to middle school and high school students. Under this project, we developed a mechanical stretcher device with improved properties that enabled live cell imaging while mechanically perturbing tissues. This device was developed in collaboration with clinicians to investigate the influence of mechanical perturbations on vascular endothelial permeability. This program also provided novel educational experiences for undergraduate researchers and increased their understanding of and appreciation for engineering research and technology in society. Participants on this project were also actively involved in several outreach initiatives at the University aimed at broadening public awareness of science and engineering in society and encouraging students to pursue careers in STEM disciplines. Students supported by this program organized instructional activities during the Girls Adventures in Mathematics, Engineering, and Science (G.A.M.E.S) camp. The G.A.M.E.S camp is a program for academically talented high school girls, who spend a week at the university learning about different fields of science through demonstrations, presentations and hands-on activities.
